show.title: Perfect Blue (Subtitled)
show.headline: The groundbreaking, must-see psychological thriller from filmmaker Satoshi Kon

event.title: <show-title>Perfect Blue (Subtitled)</show-title> <event-type-title>Remastered</event-type-title>
event.headline: The groundbreaking, must-see psychological thriller from filmmaker Satoshi Kon
event.description: Rising pop star Mima has quit singing to pursue a career as an actress and model, but her fans aren’t ready to see her go. Encouraged by her managers, Mima takes on a recurring role on a popular TV show, when suddenly her handlers and collaborators begin turning up murdered. Harboring feelings of guilt and haunted by visions of her former self, Mima’s reality and fantasy meld into a frenzied paranoia. As her stalker closes in, in person and online, the threat he poses is more real than even Mima knows, in this iconic psychological thriller that has frequently been hailed as one of the most important animated films of all time.

show.title: F*** My Son!
show.headline: Todd Rohal brings Johnny Ryan’s depraved, absurdist comic to life

event.title: <show-title>F*** My Son!</show-title><event-type-title> with Live Q&A</event-type-title>
event.headline: Live Q&A with the cast and crew
event.description:
Save your seat for a live Q&A of the Fantastic Fest Presents film FUCK MY SON! In Austin, filmmaker Todd Rohal will attend the Q&A on Nov. 1st, and actor Bryan Connolly and producer Andrew Matthews will attend the Q&A on Nov. 4th, moderated by Nathan Zellner. In L.A., Rohal will be joined by the author of the original comic, Johnny Ryan, and actors Tipper Newton, Robert Longstreet, and Steve Little.

Opening with a bargain-basement AMC theater pre-show complete with full-frontal dancing male nudity, Todd Rohal’s FUCK MY SON! adaptation is not for the faint of heart.

Expanding on Johnny Ryan’s underground comic of the same name, FUCK MY SON! is a tongue-in-cheek exploitation film in which everyone knows exactly what film they’re making.

It follows the plight of a young mother, out clothes shopping with her daughter Bernice, and teaching her hard life lessons as they catch a peeping tom watching them. If only that had been the hardest part of her day… Instead, the two try to help an old woman who’s fallen, only to quickly find the tables turned, as the old woman shoves the two in her van and kidnaps them to her secluded farmhouse.

Once there, with Bernice in a cage and the mother zip-tied to a pillar in a filthy basement, the old woman tries to make nice while she unveils her ultimate plan – to have the young woman fuck her son, at which point she’ll gladly let them go.

The nausea-inducing depravity that follows is balanced with a raunchy, bleak, absurdist humor, trademarks of both Johnny Ryan’s and Todd Rohal’s work.

Rohal is joined by long-time collaborators Steve Little and Robert Longstreet (as the old woman), along with an incredible performance from Tipper Newton as the young mother and a few other familiar faces along the way. The positively goopy practical makeup effects really bring this piece home and are provided by industry heavyweights Marcia King and Robert Kurtzman. All of this adds up to a not-to-be-missed spectacle. (Kev Dooley)

eventType.title: Live Q&A

show.title: Closer
show.headline: A complicated web of star-crossed friends & lovers

event.title: <show-title>Closer</show-title>
event.headline: A complicated web of star-crossed friends & lovers
event.description:
CLOSER is presented as part of our Luca Guadagnino and Julia Roberts Guest Select for their new film, AFTER THE HUNT.

“Lying’s the most fun a girl can have without taking her clothes off – but it’s better if you do.”

The film that inspired pop-punk songs from bands like Panic! at the Disco and Fall Out Boy, they just don’t make movies like the late Mike Nichols' prestige star-studded drama CLOSER anymore. It’s a cinematic feat that has Natalie Portman playing a manic pixie dream girl, who at one point gives Clive Owen a lap dance in a bright pink wig, and gets Julia Roberts to scream, “It tastes like you but sweeter,” in regards to Jude Law’s you-know-what. CLOSER is a sex-punched drama about messy relationships and falling in and out of love, and the tragedy all ends with the world’s most depressing indie folk song, “The Blower’s Daughter” by Damien Rice (“Did I say that I loathe you? / Did I say that I want to / Leave it all behind? / I can’t take my mind off of you”). (Jenny Nulf)

show.title: Back to the Future: 40th Anniversary
show.headline: Marty McFly's time traveling causes a chain reaction that could end his future

event.title: <show-title>Back to the Future: 40th Anniversary</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Come get heavy with Marty and Doc
event.description:
"1.21 gigawatts!”

40 years ago, Michael J. Fox and Christopher Lloyd took us on an era-hopping adventure with BACK TO THE FUTURE as the '80s raddest time-travelin' teen and his unlikely sidekick – a crazy, wild-eyed, wild-haired scientist. What rose from those flame trails is the heaviest sci-fi comedy ever made – one that is often considered "the perfect movie" without hyperbole.

Now, you’re invited to get even heavier with us at these fourth wall-busting celebrations of time-hopping DeLoreans, life jacket vests, and oedipal overtones. Come floor it with us right to 88 mph with a Johnny B. Goode air guitar contest before the show, and themed props to bring the movie magic to life, like your very own vial of Plutonium!*

*Not guaranteed to actually transport you back in time.

It’s the raucously fun celebration you might not be ready for, but your kids – your kids are gonna love it.

What rose from those flame trails is the heaviest sci-fi comedy ever made – one that is often considered "the perfect movie" without hyperbole.

show.title: The Mummy (1999)
show.headline: The sands will rise. The heavens will part. The power will be unleashed.

event.title: <show-title>The Mummy (1999)</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Presented by Super Yaki
event.description:
This show is presented with our friends over at Super Yaki, an indie apparel company that has become a cinephile favorite according to Entertainment Weekly. They rule the internet.

We have a soft spot for 1999’s THE MUMMY, with its thrilling action sequences, sweeping romance, goofy sense of humor, exotic locales, and, of course, the pure, unbridled star power of Brendan Fraser and Rachel Weisz. So we’re inviting you to journey with us to Hamunaptra as we celebrate one of our favorite pieces of ’90s popcorn cinema with THE MUMMY Movie Party.

An ancient curse. A supernatural monster. A bumbling librarian. A dude who definitely isn’t Indiana Jones. Join us for a night of grand, old-fashioned adventure.

show.title: A Matter of Life and Death
show.headline: A heavenly new 4K restoration of the Powell & Pressburger classic

landscapeHeroImage.altText: A MATTER OF LIFE AND DEATH

portraitHeroImage.altText: A MATTER OF LIFE AND DEATH

posterImages.altText: A Matter Of Life And Death 960x1400

event.title: <show-title>A Matter of Life and Death</show-title>
event.headline: A heavenly 4K restoration of the Powell & Pressburger classic
event.description:
A MATTER OF LIFE AND DEATH is presented as part of our Aziz Ansari Guest Select for his new film, GOOD FORTUNE.

I love this film. The production design and... the way they represent Heaven is truly incredible. There's a scene where there's an angel and he confronts the main character, and it was kind of similar to how Keanu's character confronts me. (Aziz Ansari)

show.title: Killer of Sheep
show.headline: The film proclaimed a national treasure by the Library of Congress

event.title: <show-title>Killer of Sheep</show-title>
event.headline: The film proclaimed a national treasure by the Library of Congress
event.description:
KILLER OF SHEEP is presented as part of our Aziz Ansari Guest Select for his new film, GOOD FORTUNE.

A big part of [GOOD FORTUNE] is showing my character Arj in the beginning and how he’s struggling in L.A. and what that’s like. I watched so many films that depict…people struggling, and I wanted to make sure when he was struggling that it didn’t feel sad or boring. If you’ve never seen KILLER OF SHEEP…it’s incredible. When you read about how the film was made, it’s an unbelievable achievement, and I love that film. (Aziz Ansari)

This is a movie I’ve never seen in a cinema and I’d love to see in a cinema – another one of my favorites. The way it's shot, this is one of the coolest movies I’ve ever seen. This was an inspiration to me. (Aziz Ansari)

show.title: Sullivan's Travels
show.headline: Preston Sturges' masterful satire of Hollywood elitism

event.title: <show-title>Sullivan's Travels</show-title>
event.headline: Preston Sturges' masterful satire of Hollywood elitism
event.description:
SULLIVAN'S TRAVELS is presented as part of our Aziz Ansari Guest Select for his new film, GOOD FORTUNE.

The movie has an incredible message about the power of comedy itself. I went through a period where I was doing more dramatic stuff and I was kind of like, "Nah, I don’t want to do comedies." I fell in love with doing comedy again and I take the message of [SULLIVAN'S TRAVELS] to heart of how valuable it is to make someone laugh and what it can mean and how it can bring people together. I watched this movie because it was weirdly what I was doing. When I was working on GOOD FORTUNE, I did gig work – I did DoorDash and was following people who worked at Home Depots and such, and interviewed all these people and really tried to understand what things people were dealing with that are similar to what my characters were dealing with. (Aziz Ansari)

event.description:
Be among the first to experience the wild new Yorgos Lanthimos-Emma Stone joint.

Two conspiracy-obsessed young men are convinced a high-powered CEO is an alien bent on destroying Earth, and they’ll stop at nothing.

Join us for a special advance screening, followed by a livestream Q&A with director Yorgos Lanthimos, actors Emma Stone and Jesse Plemons, and writer Will Tracy. Savor our special bee-themed menu, featuring Honey Thyme wings, the Bee’s Knees cocktail, and the Bee Sting mocktail.

show.title: Creepshow (1982)
show.headline: Stephen King and George Romero's horror anthology

event.title: <show-title>Creepshow (1982)</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Stephen King and George Romero's horror anthology
event.description:
Fans of Stephen King know that even though he’s written some seriously epic novels, some of his best work lies within his short stories. Whether he wants to scare you, move you, or make you laugh, he knows how to get there quickly and masterfully.

And that’s what makes CREEPSHOW so great. Alongside legendary director George Romero (NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD), King crafted a series of tales into a film that stands as the seminal ’80s horror anthology.

Featuring an amazing cast, including Adrienne Barbeau (THE FOG), Leslie Nielsen (THE NAKED GUN), and Ted Danson (BODY HEAT), CREEPSHOW is a pop-art splatterfest that’s oozing with senior citizen zombies, bad dads, furry beasties, disco dance-offs, cockroach war zones, and Stephen King turning into a plant. You can’t go wrong.

Your ticket comes with the following props:

  • Brain gummies
  • A pumpkin scoop
  • A jack-o-lantern light

show.title: Lifeforce
show.headline: A race of space vampires arrives in London and wreaks havoc on the city

event.title: <show-title>Lifeforce</show-title> <event-type-title>The International Cut</event-type-title>
event.headline: A race of space vampires arrives in London and wreaks havoc on the city
event.description: Tobe Hooper (POLTERGEIST, THE TEXAS CHAIN SAW MASSACRE (1974)) directed this lavish sci-fi horror film about a spaceship populated with beautiful humanoid aliens found hidden within Halley’s Comet. Steve Railsback is properly unhinged as the hapless astronaut who unwittingly unleashes the intergalactic menace upon the Earth, with droll support from Oscar nominees Peter Firth (EQUUS) and Frank Finlay (OTHELLO), and Mathilda May playing an enticing space vampire. A B-movie with A-list production values, LIFEFORCE features visual effects by Oscar-winner John Dykstra (STAR WARS) and a full-bodied score by the legendary Henry Mancini, conducting the London Symphony Orchestra. (Academy Museum of Motion Pictures)

titleCardImage.altText: Special Event Event Type Title Card

show.title: Night of the Living Dead (1990)
show.headline: They're coming to get you...again

event.title: <show-title>Night of the Living Dead (1990)</show-title> <event-type-title>Director's Cut</event-type-title>
event.headline: The uncut and uncensored version of Tom Savini's remake finally arrives
event.description:
The highly anticipated director's cut of NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD (1990) is uncensored and uncut, restoring graphic violence and gore cut from the theatrical version, and includes Tom Savini's original vision of starting the film in black and white and then transitioning to color as an homage to the 1968 film.

It's a new night for terror – and a new dawn in horror movie-making – when special-effects genius Tom Savini (creator of the spectacularly gruesome makeup in FRIDAY THE 13TH and CREEPSHOW) brings modern technology to this colorful remake of George A. Romero's 1968 cult classic. Seven strangers are trapped in an isolated farmhouse while cannibalistic zombies – awakened from death by the return of a radioactive space probe – wage a relentless attack, killing (and eating) everyone in their path. The classic for the '90s: graphic, gruesome, and more terrifying than ever!

show.title: The Lost Boys
show.headline: A blood-sucking ’80s classic

event.title: <show-title>The Lost Boys</show-title>
event.headline: Joel Schumacher’s 1987 bisexual hot boy bloodsucking beach bonanza!
event.description:
“We don't ride with vampires.”

We’ve been waiting for this one! After writing THE WIZ (wild information, I know) and before deciding Batman’s suit needed nipples, Joel Schumacher directed one of the subtextually queerest mainstream films of the '80s. THE LOST BOYS is '80s homoeroticism distilled into its most potent form. When Michael (Jason Patric) and Sam Emerson (Corey Haim) move to the sleepy seaside town of Santa Carla, California, with their mother Lucy (Dianne Wiest), they're worried that life will suddenly become boring. Reeling from their parents' divorce and living with their mother’s eccentric father, Michael and Sam suddenly find their lives are anything but boring when they become the targets of a local hot boy vampire gang led by punky dangly earring-ed David (Kiefer Sutherland). Can Michael and Sam resist the thrall of homoerotic vampire ecstasy, or will they fall victim to the delicious seductions of the night?

Featuring an iconic '80s soundtrack, including a shirtless jacked saxophonist cover of "I Still Believe" and the banger “Cry Little Sister” by G Tom Mac, THE LOST BOYS is boy-on-boy queer-coded shenanigans at their finest. Some folks might argue with us that there is heterosexual romance in this film, but we disagree. I mean, every time they say the word “vampire,” it sounds like a gay slur, y’all. Sure, there’s always the incredible Star (Jami Gertz), but being drawn to a beautiful woman with giant hair isn’t straight – it’s actually super gay. Gays love big hair – it’s in our DNA. But for real though, THE LOST BOYS is Joel Schumacher at his most transparent; the dude wanted to make a movie about hot vampy boys and he did. And we’re not mad about it. Predating the brooding gaze of Edward Cullen, THE LOST BOYS was instrumental in bringing vampires one step further toward the sexy end of the sexy vs. scary spectrum, and we can’t wait to celebrate this camp classic with y’all on the big screen.

event.title: <show-title>Day of the Dead (1985)</show-title> <event-type-title>40th Anniversary</event-type-title>
event.headline: Experience the final chapter of the ultimate zombie trilogy on the big screen
event.description: George A. Romero’s DAY OF THE DEAD, the apocalyptic final chapter of the ultimate zombie trilogy, returns to theaters for its 40th anniversary! Whole generations of horror lovers have never seen any of Romero’s zombie classics in theaters. Now in 2025, Red Band is thrilled for the opportunity to help fellow George A. Romero fans celebrate the 40th anniversary of the original DAY OF THE DEAD by seeing it as the legendary director intended – on the big screen!

show.title: Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?
show.headline: An evening of dysfunctional relationships, hosted by Burton & Taylor

event.title: <show-title>Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?</show-title>
event.headline: An evening of dysfunctional relationships, hosted by Burton & Taylor
event.description:
WHO'S AFRAID OF VIRGINIA WOOLF? is presented as part of our Luca Guadagnino and Julia Roberts Guest Select for their new film, AFTER THE HUNT.

Whoo boy, nothing will make you feel better about your relationship (or lack of) like spending a boozy evening with Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton. The real-life on-again-off-again couple is downright combustible in Mike Nichols’ big-screen directorial debut, an envelope-pushing adaptation of Edward Albee’s play. It will probably come as no surprise to learn that this served as inspiration for The Office's iconic "Dinner Party" episode.

George (Burton) is an alcoholic college professor. Martha (Taylor) is his loud and overbearing wife. Together, they know just how to push each other's buttons. Tiring of attacking each other, George and Martha invite newcomers Nick and Honey (George Segal and Sandy Dennis) to join them for drinks one night after a faculty party. During the course of the evening, both marriages are dissected, painful truths are revealed, and long-established ways of coping are destroyed.

Besides being a box office success, scoring an Oscar win for Taylor and launching Nichols into hot young Hollywood director status, WHO’S AFRAID OF VIRGINIA WOOLF? is, as Stanley Kauffmann of the New York Times calls it, “one of the most scathingly honest American films ever made.”

Watching with a cocktail in hand isn’t required, but very much advised.

image.altText: WHO'S AFRAID OF VIRGINIA WOOLF? trailer

marketStrings.value: The personal closed captioning device displays feature film dialogue and other audio in the form of English-language text for individuals who are deaf or hard of hearing.

The descriptive audio headset provides individuals who are blind or have low vision with an English-language narration of the details of the feature presentation that can't be understood by the soundtrack alone.

Upon request at the box office, we provide assistive listening headsets with amplified audio for those individuals who are hard of hearing. For guests who prefer to use their own hearing aids, neck loops, or cochlear implants, our assistive listening headsets have a 3.5mm headphone jack to connect to those devices.

In order to ensure the highest quality experience for all guests, you may not enter a movie after it has started. We’d love to see you up to 30 minutes early. Running late? No worries, we will happily exchange your ticket for a different showtime or a raincheck to a future show.

sessionAttributes.name: Baby Day Show
sessionAttributes.description: For our baby day shows, we keep the lights up a bit, and the sound down a bit, so your little one never has to know they even went to the movies!
